title: Artificial Intelligence in a Mobile (AIM) Intervention for Depression
description_brief: This study will evaluate and compare a smartphone intervention for depression and anxiety that uses machine learning to tailor treatment for participants with the same intervention without the machine learning component. The intervention, referred to as IntelliCare, delivers participant-specific treatment material and motivational messaging via a mobile phone to help individuals with depression and/or anxiety. Information and data received from the participant will inform the tailored treatment approach through machine learning. The purpose of this study is to compare different versions of the main IntelliCare Hub App (the centralized program delivery system) and participant user experience whether with the support of a coach or used independently. The randomized clinical trial (RCT) aims to obtain information on the feasibility and effectiveness of IntelliCare in improving symptoms of depression and anxiety.
description_detailed:
Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a common mental disorder, with up to 10.3% of the population experiencing the disorder in a given 12-month period. The relationship between depression and anxiety has been well documented. Depression is a significant predictor of future anxiety, and anxiety is a significant predictor of future onset of depression. Indeed, studies find that more than 50% of all individuals with MDD also have a current anxiety disorder. Although effective treatments have been developed over the years to address depression and anxiety, the lack of personalization and inability to adapt to patient needs or preferences contributes to poor treatment adherence and outcomes.

An intelligent treatment system was developed that uses state of the art machine learning approaches within a mobile intervention application to treat MDD and anxiety. Machine learning, a branch of artificial intelligence, focuses on the development of algorithms that automatically improve and evolve based on collected data. The intervention, called IntelliCare, uses a mobile application to continuously collect patient data and adapt intervention content and motivational messaging to create a highly tailored and user-responsive treatment system.

During the RCT study, 270 participants with Major Depression and/or Anxiety will use IntelliCare apps for up to 8 weeks and will be invited to complete online questionnaires at four follow-up time points: weeks 4 and 8 in the study program, and months 3 and 6 after the study program ends. All participants will first undergo initial assessments that will include a telephone interview and a series of online questionnaires about their mood. Eligible participants will receive up to 8 weeks of access to the IntelliCare system, which consists of apps with lessons and tools designed to teach skills for mood management. It is suggested that participants utilize the mobile phone tools every day.

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two versions of the IntelliCare Hub App, which is the central delivery system for the IntelliCare program, and participants will also be randomly assigned to get support from a human coach or use the IntelliCare program independently.

Each week, participants assigned to work with a coach will receive a brief motivational intervention. This coach will also be available to participants via email throughout the 8 week study. Participants randomly assigned to use the IntelliCare program independently will receive an on-boarding guide to set up the IntelliCare Hub App on their phone, and participants will have access to our tech support team if technical difficulties arise while using the program.

Data from the RCT study will be used to examine whether: the IntelliCare program is an effective intervention for reducing depressive and anxiety symptoms; the recommender system will produce greater program adherence and; support from a coach or independent use might affect user experience and adherence. Data collected will also be used to further develop and evaluate machine learning methods for future research and deployment efforts.

measures.title: Sex: Female, Male
measures.populationDescription: Participants were provided option to not answer, or to answer not applicable.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: Patient Health Questionaire 9 (PHQ-9)
measures.description: A nine-item scale that assesses how often the respondent felt depressed over the last two weeks. Each item is scored on 0, not at all-3, nearly every day. The total score on the scale ranges from 0 (no depression) to 27 (severe depression).

measures.title: Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7 (GAD-7)
measures.description: A 7 item scale that measures how often a respondent has felt anxious over the past 2 weeks. Each item is scored on a 0 (not at all)-3 (nearly every day) scale. The total score ranges from 0 (Not anxious) to 21 (Very anxious)

outcomeMeasures.title: Adherence to the Mobile Application Intervention
outcomeMeasures.description: Defined as the median time to last engagement with the mobile application suite within 8 weeks of trial
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of the 8 week trial

analyses.groupDescription: Log-rank test of adherence, defined as time to last engagement with mobile application suite.
analyses.statisticalComment: Chi square= 4.1 on 3 degrees of freedom

outcomeMeasures.title: Patient Health Questionnaire - 9 (PHQ-9) - Depression Severity
outcomeMeasures.description: The PHQ-9 measures degree of depression severity. Possible range of scores for the PHQ-9 is 0-27. Higher values represent a worse outcome. Specifically, scores of 0-4 indicate minimal or no depression; 5-9 is mild; 10-14 is moderate; 15-19 is moderately severe; and 20-27 is severe.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Participants with at least one follow-up measure of self-reported depression
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Measured at start of treatment (baseline), week 4, week 8, month 3, and month 6.

analyses.groupDescription: Interactive effect of time and group, adjusting for baseline PHQ-9, randomization strata, main and interactive effects of time, coach, coach\*time, hub, and hub\*time.

outcomeMeasures.title: GAD-7 (Generalized Anxiety Disorder Scale-7) - Anxiety Severity
outcomeMeasures.description: The GAD-7 is a self-administered 7 item instrument that uses some of the DSM-V criteria for GAD (General Anxiety Disorder) to identify probable cases of GAD along with measuring anxiety symptom severity. GAD-7 total score for the seven items ranges from 0 to 21. Higher values represent a worse outcome. Specifically, scores of 1-4 indicate minimal anxiety symptoms; 5-9 is mild anxiety symptoms; 10-14 is moderate anxiety symptoms; and 15-21 is severe anxiety symptoms.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Participants with at least one follow-up measure of self-reported anxiety
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Measured at start of treatment (baseline), week 4, week 8, month 3, and month 6.

explanation_target: Reason: The described intervention (IntelliCare / AIM) is a smartphone-based, machine-learning–tailored program intended to reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety (psychiatric symptoms), not a biologic or small-molecule agent nor a cognitive-restoration drug. Therefore it matches the definition of an intervention aimed at neuropsychiatric symptom improvement. citeturn0search4turn0search7

Act: Key details extracted — intervention name: IntelliCare (a suite of brief, skills-focused mobile apps organized by a Hub that delivers app recommendations and messaging). The study compares Hub/App versions with and without the ML tailoring and with/without coach support; no drug or placebo is involved. IntelliCare has been tested in RCTs for depression and anxiety and uses a Hub recommender to tailor app delivery. citeturn0search1turn0search7turn0search4

Reflect: Classification check — this is not a disease-targeted biologic or small molecule, and it is not described as a cognitive-enhancer (improving memory/attention via pharmacology). It is a behavioral/digital therapeutic targeting psychiatric symptoms (depression/anxiety), so the correct category is 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement'. Note: the trial description does not involve drugs or placebo, and the web sources above document IntelliCare's purpose and prior RCT results. citeturn0search7turn0search4
explanation_agent: Reason: The described intervention (IntelliCare / AIM) is a smartphone-based, machine‑learning–tailored behavioral/digital therapeutic intended to reduce symptoms of depression and anxiety, not a biologic, small molecule, or a treatment acting on a defined molecular/cellular pathway in the CADRO scheme. This means there is no CADRO therapeutic target (e.g., amyloid, tau, inflammation, neurotransmitter receptor) described. citeturn0search2turn0search1

Act: Key details extracted from the trial description and publications — intervention name: IntelliCare (a suite of brief, skills‑focused mobile apps organized by a Hub that provides weekly app recommendations via a recommender system and uses machine learning/AI to tailor delivery); study compares Hub/App versions (recommender ML vs not) and coach support vs self‑guided; primary outcomes are symptom scales (PHQ‑9, GAD‑7). No drug, biologic, or molecular target is involved. citeturn0search2turn0search1turn0search6

Reflect: Classification check — because the intervention is behavioral/digital and symptom‑focused (depression/anxiety), and does not act via a named CADRO biological target or pathway, the appropriate CADRO assignment is 'T) Other' (non‑therapeutic / no CADRO target). An alternative (e.g., D) would only apply if a pharmacologic agent targeting neurotransmitter receptors were used, which it is not. citeturn0search3turn0search4

- "Comparison of the Effects of Coaching and Receipt of App Recommendations on Depression, Anxiety, and Engagement in the IntelliCare Platform: Factorial Randomized Controlled Trial" (PubMed) — describes IntelliCare platform, coaching, and app recommendations. citeturn0search1

- "IntelliCare Study: Artificial Intelligence in a Mobile (AIM) Intervention for Depression" (trial description / MedPath / ClinicalTrials summary) — describes the AIM trial details, machine learning recommender, and outcomes. citeturn0search2turn0search3

- "Evaluation of a recommender app for apps for the treatment of depression and anxiety: an analysis of longitudinal user engagement" (PubMed) — analysis of the Hub recommender and engagement in the IntelliCare suite. citeturn0search6

Conclusion / Output: {"category": "T) Other"} — The AIM/IntelliCare intervention is a digital behavioral treatment for neuropsychiatric symptoms (depression/anxiety) and does not map to any CADRO biological target category, so it is classified as 'T) Other'.
